importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The article references an update at 11:55 PM EDT on October 20, 2025, indicating the current status of Trump-Putin summit discussions.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The pre-meeting between Rubio and Lavrov was scheduled for this week but has been tabled, placing the current status of diplomatic talks within a short timeframe leading into the anticipated Trump-Putin summit.

keyTakeAways: President Donald Trump expressed hope for a swift summit with Russian President Vladimir Putin, citing a mutual agreement on high-level advisor meetings.
An anticipated pre-meeting between U.S. Secretary of State Marco Rubio and Russian foreign minister Sergey Lavrov has been postponed due to divergent views on ending Russia's invasion of Ukraine.
Rubio and Lavrov had previously discussed 'next steps' to resolve the conflict, but officials believe the Russian position has not significantly changed from its maximalist stance.
The White House emphasizes Trump’s consistent push for peace and diplomatic solutions to end the war, asserting his commitment to engaging all parties.
Trump previously met Putin in Anchorage in late 2024, with that summit ending without a deal; he has since repeatedly called for an immediate halt to hostilities.
The Kremlin characterized the Rubio-Lavrov call as a 'constructive discussion' focused on implementing understandings between the leaders.
It remains uncertain whether the postponement of the pre-meeting will affect the eventual Trump-Putin summit scheduled in Budapest, Hungary.

namedEntities.name: Donald Trump
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Trump is the central figure driving diplomatic efforts to end the war in Ukraine, with direct calls to Putin and public advocacy for an immediate ceasefire. His leadership and vision are crucial to the global relevance of the summit discussions.

namedEntities.name: Vladimir Putin
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Putin is the key counterpart to Trump in the proposed summit; their negotiations are central to the article's focus on diplomatic progress or failure in ending the Ukraine war.

namedEntities.name: Marco Rubio
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Rubio is a central figure in the pre-meeting with Lavrov and represents U.S. foreign policy on Ukraine, making his stance critical to the feasibility of the Trump-Putin summit.

namedEntities.name: Sergey Lavrov
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Lavrov is the primary Russian diplomatic point of contact with Rubio, and their differing views on ending the war are a major factor in the delay of the pre-summit meeting.

namedEntities.name: Hungary
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The anticipated location of the Trump-Putin summit in Budapest, Hungary, places the event in a geopolitical context involving European diplomacy and international relations.

namedEntities.name: Ukraine
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The ongoing Russian invasion of Ukraine is the core issue being discussed in the diplomatic talks, making it the central concern driving all interactions between Trump, Putin, Rubio, and Lavrov.

namedEntities.name: Anchorage, Alaska
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This is the site of the last in-person Trump-Putin summit, which ended without a deal, providing context for the renewed hopes and current challenges in diplomacy.

namedEntities.name: Truth Social
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Trump used Truth Social to communicate his position on the need for a meeting with Putin, indicating the role of digital platforms in modern political messaging.

namedEntities.name: CNN
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: CNN is the source of the article, providing a reputable media context for reporting on U.S.-Russia diplomatic developments.

namedEntities.name: White House
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The White House is the source of official statements, including Deputy Press Secretary Anna Kelly’s comments on Trump’s commitment to peace.

namedEntities.name: State Department
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The State Department issued a readout of the Rubio-Lavrov call, providing an official record of diplomatic communication.

summaryOfNewsArticle: President Donald Trump’s efforts to secure a quick summit with Russian President Vladimir Putin may be delayed after an expected pre-meeting between U.S. Secretary of State Marco Rubio and Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov was tabled due to divergent positions on ending Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. Despite Trump’s public calls for an immediate ceasefire and his previous in-person summit in Anchorage, officials believe the Russian stance has not evolved significantly, leading to a pause in diplomatic progress. The White House reaffirms Trump’s commitment to peace, while the Kremlin calls the recent call between Rubio and Lavrov a 'constructive discussion.' It remains unclear whether the delay will affect the planned Trump-Putin summit in Budapest, Hungary, though Rubio and Lavrov may meet again this week.
title: Trump’s hope for quick second summit with Putin may be stalled as pre-meeting tabled for now
